abstract.p: Howard Goldberg reviews Eroica reisling wine and notes its availability in New York City; photo (M)

block.p: Beethoven composed the first ''Eroica.'' The Middle Mosel and Washington State collaborated on the second.

Beethoven composed the first ''Eroica.'' The Middle Mosel and Washington State collaborated on the second.
Eroica, the wine (not the Third Symphony), is arriving in shops at a moment when riesling yearns to take center stage in America.

Crisp, light, smooth, the elegant '99 white is a joint venture of Weingut Dr. Loosen (pronounced LOW-zen), an influential German estate, and Chateau Ste. Michelle, the Pacific Northwest's No. 1 producer.
More a haute cuisine than an apertif wine, Eroica wants to be interpreted as a Washington riesling with German inflections.
The idea was born when, after sampling a Ste. Michelle dry riesling, Ernst Loosen (pictured TK) proposed a joint venture.
Old World and New World grape-growing and harvest techniques fused at Ste. Michelle, principally in its fine Cold Creek Vineyard, in the desertlike Columbia River Valley.

Similarly, separate cultural values, ideas and practices mingled during the cellar, importantly in the step-by-step blending that sought and artfully achieved a high-wire balance among fruit, acidity and alcohol.

Eroica -- poised, subtle, a complete wine -- is worth the $20 charged at Ambassador Wines, 1020 Second Avenue (54th Street), Columbus Circle Liquor, 1780 Broadway (57th Street) and 67 Wine, 179 Columbus Avenue (68th Street), all in Manhattan.

When Eroica is carefully, mildly chilled, aromas and flavors of delicate peaches and dry apricots emerge; though dry, it leaves an impression of a tinge of sweetness; the clinging finish, a hallmark of finesse, is extra long.

Only 2,400 bottles are entering national distribution; alas, curiosity, thirst and hunger will uncork almost all prematurely. The few rarities unhoarded almost certainly will soar in value at auction.
